To come from a different perspective than most of the other posts so far, I would say look for other large Catholic families that you and your family can “hang out” with. My wife is pregnant with #6 right now, and many of our closest friends have 7 or more. Not only does it make it enjoyable to have other kids for our kids to play with, but the interaction between my wife and her friends I think makes it easier for her to deal with going through so many pregnancies on her own.

item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:11, topic:472760”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=590571.msg4180805#msg4180805 date=1355509586]

Thank you for the clarification. I was under the impression that this had not already been done, or that this was the OP’s idea. If this is indeed true, then she is committing a sin. If you are going to engage in sex with your husband, you cannot make sinful requirements or use guilt to pervert the act. That is very manipulation, though she might not realize this.
[/quote]The point is that there are times in every marriage where a periodic abstinence is suffered. It may be because is an illness, chronic or acute, an injury, or perhaps some type of psychological issue. It is important to keep the perspective that these things are temporary, and a way to become spiritually stronger. Who knows, God may have placed this cross on one’s shoulder to be strong enough to fight a worse temptation in the near future.

I agree with what you have said and understand the marital debt the same way. We don’t know the reason why the wife does not want anymore children right now. Her reason may be grave. Until we know for certain, I wouldn’t assume that her reason is without merit, but we don’t have that information. Also, though it may be advisable, I do not believe that it is required to get approval from a priest to use NFP. Obviously, if you are unsure, or there is a disagreement or confusion on grave matters - yes, consult a priest, but I don’t believe it is actually required.[/quote]With the way you interpreted the OP’s quote, I understand the conclusion you came to, these things cannot be taken lightly.

Okay, here goes. I have quite a situation that I need help with. My wife is not wanting more children right now (we have four), so the only way we can have relations is if I don’t “finish the act,” if you will. Yes, I’m talking withdrawal. It’s killing me because I don’t want to have mortal sin on my soul, yet I also believe in “happy wife, happy life.” I feel that she’s being selfish and not trusting God. Sometimes I try to convince myself that it’s not a mortal sin on my part because I want to do what’s right and it’s not my desire to sin. We’ve tried abstinence, but it doesn’t work for me. And please don’t start hitting me over the head; this is difficult enough as it is.

[/quote]Homosexuals are required to abstain. If the Church can ask them to do it, anyone can. If abstinence “doesn’t work for you” then it’s not because it’s too difficult, it’s because you don’t love God as much as you love sex.[/quote]What a ridiculous response. You’re trying to compare homosexuals to a MARRIED man. A married man is not required to abstain. His wife cannot deny him the marital debt without a very good reason, and without speaking to a priest first. Not wanting to have any more children is not a reason to abstain. What is the purpose of marriage, after all? To tell this man that he doesn’t love God enough is disgusting.
